CatDescriptText: Mr. William Morgan, 2133 Wylie Avenue, and Mr. William Beach, 2908 E. Carson Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 9, 1958, pg. 3 with question: "Do you think Negro laborers and skilled mechanics are getting a fair deal on the Lower Hill redevelopment program, or in private construction?" William Morgan's answer reads: "No, they are not getting a fair deal. Contractors are hiring more white than colored.  They turned me down on account of color and age.  I'm 73, but can still do a good day's work.  Travelers get jobs before local men."  William Beach's answer reads: "No, they are not getting a fair deal because the Negro laboring man does not get an opportunity to serve as an apprentice.  Only white apprentices are selected."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of William Morgan, wearing light colored pants with keys and chain, plaid button down collared shirt with rolled up sleeves, and William Beach with three cigars in breast pocket, standing on street with automobiles and buildings in background
